Burgundy truffle | image = Tuber aestivum Valnerina 018.jpg | image_caption = Summer truffle, cut open | genus = Tuber | species = aestivum | authority = [[Carlo Vittadini|Vittad.]] (1831) | synonyms = *''Tuber uncinatum'' [[Gaspard Adolphe Chatin|Chatin]] (1892) }} {{mycomorphbox | name=''Tuber aestivum'' | whichGills=NA | capShape=NA | hymeniumType=gleba | stipeCharacter=NA | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=blackish-brown | sporePrintColor2=brown | howEdible=choice }} The '''summer truffle''' (''Tuber aestivum'') or '''burgundy truffle''' (''Tuber uncinatum'') is a species of [[truffle]], found in almost all European countries.[https://books.google.com/books?id=taQGqqcaEYoC&pg=PA107 Hall et al., 106-110] ==Taxonomy== In cuisine and commerce, particularly in France and Italy, the summer truffle (''T. aestivum'') is distinguished from the burgundy truffle (''T. uncinatum''). However, molecular analysis showed in 2004 that these two varieties of truffle are one [[species]]. The differences between them are therefore likely due to environmental factors.[https://books.google.com/books?id=taQGqqcaEYoC&pg=PA61 Hall et al., 61-63]Paolocci et al. This article uses the older of the two [[binomial name]]s, ''T. aestivum'', to designate the species,As recommended by Hall et al., 63. while discussing the characteristics of the two varieties separately. ==Burgundy truffles== Burgundy truffles ({{lang-fr|truffe de Bourgogne}}; {{lang-it|tartufo nero di [[Fragno]]}} or ''scorzone'', "bark"; {{lang-es|trufa de verano}}; {{lang-sv|svart sommartryffel}}), have an intense, [[hazelnut]]-like aroma and are highly prized for their gastronomic qualities. They are used in the ''[[haute cuisine]]'' of France and Italy, as well as a substitute for the Périgord black truffle (''[[Tuber melanosporum|T. melanosporum]]''). Like other truffles, they are also canned and bottled for export. With bodies ([[ascocarp]]s) from {{convert|2|cm|in|0}} to {{convert|10|cm|in|0}} in diameter, burgundy truffles are relatively large. Their brown or black outer skin ([[peridium]]) forms pyramidal warts about 3 to 9 mm wide, resembling rough [[Bark (botany)|bark]]. Burgundy truffles are harvested from September to late December, sometimes also until late January. They have a wider distribution than any other truffle species. Burgundy truffles are found across Europe, from Spain to eastern Europe and from Sweden to North Africa. In France they are found mainly in the north-east and in Italy, in the north. In the United Kingdom they were plentiful prior to the 20th century, but are now rare. Their distribution may not yet be definitively established: there are as of 2007 unconfirmed reports of findings in China. ==Summer truffles== The flavor, size and color of summer truffles ({{lang-it|tartufo estivo}}) is similar to that of burgundy truffles, but their aroma is less intense and the flesh ([[gleba]]) is a paler hazel color. As their name suggests, summer truffles are harvested earlier than burgundy truffles, from May to August. They are most often found in the southern part of the distribution area of the species, notably in the [[Mediterranean climate]] areas of France, Italy and Spain. ==See also== *[[List of Tuber (fungus) species|List of ''Tuber'' species]] ==References== *{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Ian R.|title=Taming the truffle: the history, lore, and science of the ultimate mushroom|year=2007|publisher=Timber Press|isbn=978-0-88192-860-0|author2=Gordon Thomas Brown|author3=Alessandra Zambonelli|chapter=Burgundy or Summer Truffle|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/tamingtrufflehis00hall}} *{{cite journal|last=Paolocci|first=Francesco|author2=Andrea Rubini |author3=Claudia Riccioni |author4=Fabiana Topini |author5=Sergio Arcioni |title=''Tuber aestivum'' and ''Tuber uncinatum'': two morphotypes or two species?|journal=[[FEMS Microbiology Letters]]|date=June 2004|volume=235|issue=1|pages=109–115|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6968.2004.tb09574.x|pmid=15158269}} *{{cite journal|last=Gryndler|first=Milan |author2=Hana Hršelová |author3=Lucie Soukupová |author4=Eva Streiblová |author5=Slavomír Valda |author6=Jan Borovička |author7=Hana Gryndlerová |author8=Ján Gažo |author9=Marián Miko|title=Detection of summer truffle (''Tuber aestivum'' Vittad.) in ectomycorrhizae and in soil using specific primers|journal=[[FEMS Microbiology Letters]]|date=May 2011|volume=318|issue=1|pages=84–91|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6968.2011.02243.x|pmid=21385201}} {{Reflist}} ===Footnotes=== *{{commons category inline|Tuber aestivum}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q74692|from2=Q3541785}} [[Category:Tuber (fungus)]] [[Category:Truffles (fungi)]] [[Category:Fungi described in 1831]]
